Apple___Apple_scab.description: Fungal disease causing dark, scabby lesions on leaves and fruits

chemical_treatments.name: Mancozeb 75% WP
chemical_treatments.application: Spray every 10-15 days during rainy season

chemical_treatments.name: Carbendazim 50% WP
chemical_treatments.application: Spray at 15-day intervals

organic_treatments.name: Neem Oil
organic_treatments.application: Spray weekly on affected plants

organic_treatments.name: Baking Soda Solution
organic_treatments.dosage: 1 tbsp soda + 1 tbsp oil per liter
organic_treatments.application: Spray every 7 days

prevention_tips: Remove and destroy infected leaves immediately
Prune trees to improve air circulation
Avoid overhead watering
Apply fungicides before rainy season
Plant resistant varieties
Apple___Apple_scab.when_to_treat: Treat immediately when spots appear. Best results in early stage.

Apple___healthy.description: No disease detected. Leaf is healthy.
prevention_tips: Continue regular monitoring
Maintain proper watering schedule
Ensure adequate nutrition
Keep area clean from fallen leaves
Regular inspection for early detection
Apple___healthy.when_to_treat: No treatment needed. Continue preventive care.

Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.description: Fungal disease causing gray rectangular lesions on corn leaves

chemical_treatments.name: Propiconazole 25% EC
chemical_treatments.application: Spray at first sign of disease, repeat at 15-day intervals

chemical_treatments.name: Azoxystrobin + Difenoconazole
chemical_treatments.application: Apply at tasseling stage, repeat if needed

chemical_treatments.name: Tebuconazole 25% EC
chemical_treatments.application: Spray when lesions first appear

organic_treatments.name: Trichoderma harzianum
organic_treatments.application: Spray every 15 days starting from 30 days after planting

organic_treatments.name: Garlic + Chili Extract
organic_treatments.application: Spray weekly on affected plants

organic_treatments.name: Neem Oil + Soap
organic_treatments.dosage: 5ml neem oil + few drops soap per liter
organic_treatments.application: Spray twice weekly

prevention_tips: Plant resistant maize hybrids
Rotate crops with non-host crops (soybean, wheat) for 2-3 years
Plow under or remove crop residue immediately after harvest
Avoid planting in poorly drained areas
Increase plant spacing for better air circulation
Apply balanced fertilization, avoid excess nitrogen
Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.when_to_treat: Treat when lesions first appear on leaves, especially before tasseling. Late treatment is less effective.

Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.description: Serious fungal disease causing long cigar-shaped gray-green lesions on corn leaves
causes: Infected crop debris left in field

chemical_treatments.name: Mancozeb 75% WP
chemical_treatments.application: Spray at 10-15 day intervals, start when disease first appears

chemical_treatments.name: Tebuconazole 25% EC
chemical_treatments.application: Apply at disease onset, repeat after 15 days

chemical_treatments.name: Propiconazole 25% EC
chemical_treatments.application: Spray when lower leaves show symptoms

organic_treatments.name: Bacillus subtilis
organic_treatments.application: Spray every 10 days as preventive measure

organic_treatments.name: Neem + Turmeric Paste
organic_treatments.application: Spray twice weekly on affected plants

organic_treatments.name: Copper Oxychloride 50% WP
organic_treatments.application: Spray at 10-day intervals

prevention_tips: Use resistant or tolerant maize varieties
Completely bury or remove all crop residue after harvest
Rotate crops - avoid planting maize for 2-3 years in infected fields
Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilizer which promotes disease
Plant at recommended spacing to ensure good air circulation
Scout fields regularly, especially lower leaves
Avoid overhead irrigation if possible
Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.when_to_treat: Begin treatment immediately when lesions first appear on lower leaves. Do not wait for disease to spread upward to upper leaves.

Grape___Black_rot.description: Devastating fungal disease affecting all green parts of grape vines, causing fruit to rot and mummify
causes: Poor vineyard sanitation with mummified fruit left on vines

chemical_treatments.name: Copper Oxychloride 50% WP
chemical_treatments.application: Spray before flowering, after fruit set, and during berry development

chemical_treatments.name: Hexaconazole 5% EC
chemical_treatments.application: Apply at 15-day intervals during rainy season

chemical_treatments.name: Mancozeb 75% WP
chemical_treatments.application: Spray from bud break through harvest at 10-14 day intervals

organic_treatments.name: Bordeaux Mixture
organic_treatments.application: Spray before rain, repeat after heavy rain

organic_treatments.name: Trichoderma Viride
organic_treatments.application: Spray every 10 days throughout growing season

organic_treatments.name: Potassium Bicarbonate
organic_treatments.application: Spray weekly during humid periods

prevention_tips: Remove ALL mummified fruits from vines and ground before spring
Prune vines to ensure excellent air circulation and sunlight penetration
Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilizer which promotes lush growth
Plant resistant grape varieties if available
Sanitize all pruning tools between cuts
Keep vineyard floor clean and weed-free
Apply dormant spray with lime sulfur before bud break
Grape___Black_rot.when_to_treat: Start treatment IMMEDIATELY when first spots appear. Black rot spreads extremely rapidly during warm, humid weather. Preventive sprays are critical.

Grape___Leaf_blight.description: Fungal disease causing irregular brown lesions with yellow halos, leading to premature defoliation
causes: Multiple fungal pathogens including Pseudocercospora vitis
High humidity and poor air circulation

chemical_treatments.name: Mancozeb 75% WP
chemical_treatments.application: Spray at 10-day intervals during rainy season

chemical_treatments.name: Chlorothalonil 75% WP
chemical_treatments.application: Apply every 2 weeks, alternate with other fungicides

chemical_treatments.name: Carbendazim 50% WP
chemical_treatments.application: Spray at 15-day intervals

organic_treatments.name: Neem Oil + Garlic Extract
organic_treatments.dosage: 5ml neem oil + 10ml garlic extract per liter
organic_treatments.application: Spray weekly, especially undersides of leaves

organic_treatments.name: Cow Urine Fermented Solution
organic_treatments.dosage: 100ml fermented cow urine per liter water
organic_treatments.application: Spray twice a week early morning

organic_treatments.name: Baking Soda Spray
organic_treatments.application: Spray every 5-7 days

prevention_tips: Remove and destroy all infected leaves immediately
Improve air circulation by proper pruning and thinning
Avoid overhead irrigation - use drip irrigation at soil level
Apply thick organic mulch to prevent soil splash onto leaves
Ensure adequate spacing between vines (minimum 6-8 feet)
Remove weeds that block airflow
Apply preventive fungicides before monsoon season
Grape___Leaf_blight.when_to_treat: Treat as soon as first symptoms appear on leaves. Disease is most manageable in early stages before widespread defoliation occurs.

Grape___healthy.description: No disease detected. Vine and leaves are healthy.
prevention_tips: Continue current vineyard care practices
Monitor vines regularly for any disease signs
Maintain proper nutrition with balanced fertilization
Ensure excellent vineyard sanitation
Check for insect pests weekly
Prune regularly for good air circulation
Grape___healthy.when_to_treat: No treatment needed. Continue preventive monitoring and good cultural practices.

Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).description: MOST DEVASTATING citrus disease worldwide. Bacterial infection transmitted by Asian citrus psyllid. NO CURE EXISTS. Infected trees will die within 3-5 years.
causes: Transmitted exclusively by Asian citrus psyllid insect
Use of infected budwood or nursery plants
Cannot spread by direct tree contact or soil

chemical_treatments.name: Imidacloprid 17.8% SL (PSYLLID CONTROL ONLY)
chemical_treatments.application: Soil drench every 6 months to kill psyllid vectors

chemical_treatments.name: Thiamethoxam 25% WG (PSYLLID CONTROL)
chemical_treatments.application: Foliar spray monthly during psyllid season

chemical_treatments.name: Nutrient Supplements (Zinc, Manganese, Iron)
chemical_treatments.application: Foliar spray monthly to reduce symptoms temporarily

organic_treatments.name: Neem Oil (PSYLLID CONTROL ONLY)
organic_treatments.application: Spray every 10 days targeting new flush where psyllids feed

organic_treatments.name: Horticultural Oil
organic_treatments.application: Spray on new growth to suffocate psyllid eggs and nymphs

organic_treatments.name: Yellow Sticky Traps
organic_treatments.application: Place traps to monitor and catch adult psyllids

prevention_tips: IMMEDIATELY remove and DESTROY any infected tree (burn or bury deep) to prevent spread
Control Asian citrus psyllid population AGGRESSIVELY with insecticides
Use ONLY certified disease-free nursery plants from registered nurseries
NEVER use budwood from unknown or backyard sources
Monitor ALL citrus trees in area every 2 weeks for symptoms
Apply systemic insecticides preventively every 6 months
Cover young trees with insect-proof nets (50-mesh)
Maintain tree nutrition to slow symptom development
Report suspected cases to agricultural authorities immediately
Orange___Haunglongbing_(Citrus_greening).when_to_treat: CRITICAL: There is NO CURE for HLB. Focus entirely on PREVENTION and aggressive PSYLLID CONTROL. Once a tree is infected, it MUST be removed immediately to protect other trees. Do not waste money on treatments for infected trees - remove them!

Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.description: Fungal disease causing purple to brown spots with scorched leaf margins, reducing plant vigor and fruit yield
causes: Water splash from rain or overhead irrigation spreading spores
Infected plant material or contaminated soil

chemical_treatments.name: Captan 50% WP
chemical_treatments.application: Spray every 10-14 days during growing season

chemical_treatments.name: Azoxystrobin 23% SC
chemical_treatments.application: Apply at 2-week intervals, maximum 3 applications per season

chemical_treatments.name: Myclobutanil 10% WP
chemical_treatments.application: Spray at first sign of disease

organic_treatments.name: Neem Oil
organic_treatments.application: Spray weekly during humid weather, cover both leaf surfaces

organic_treatments.name: Copper Sulfate (Organic formulation)
organic_treatments.application: Apply before rainy season as preventive

organic_treatments.name: Bacillus subtilis
organic_treatments.application: Spray every 7-10 days throughout season

prevention_tips: Remove and destroy old infected leaves before new growth starts
Use drip irrigation instead of overhead sprinklers
Space plants adequately (12-15 inches apart) for good air circulation
Apply thick straw mulch around plants to prevent soil splash
Use resistant strawberry varieties when available
Renovate strawberry beds immediately after harvest
Remove weeds that block airflow and harbor disease
Avoid working in wet strawberry beds
Strawberry___Leaf_scorch.when_to_treat: Start treatment when first purple spots appear on leaves. Disease is much easier to control in early stages before extensive leaf damage.

Tomato___Bacterial_spot.description: Serious bacterial disease causing dark greasy spots on leaves, stems and fruits, leading to severe defoliation and fruit damage
causes: Water splash from rain or overhead irrigation
Warm wet conditions (25-30°C with high humidity)
Wounds from insects or mechanical damage

chemical_treatments.name: Streptocycline 9% + Tetracycline 1%
chemical_treatments.application: Spray at 10-day intervals, maximum 3 applications

chemical_treatments.name: Copper Hydroxide 77% WP
chemical_treatments.application: Apply weekly during disease-favorable weather

chemical_treatments.name: Copper Oxychloride 50% WP
chemical_treatments.application: Spray at 7-10 day intervals

organic_treatments.name: Pseudomonas fluorescens
organic_treatments.application: Spray every 7 days as preventive and curative

organic_treatments.name: Fermented Neem Cake Extract
organic_treatments.dosage: 50 grams neem cake fermented in water per liter
organic_treatments.application: Spray twice weekly

organic_treatments.name: Garlic + Ginger Extract
organic_treatments.application: Spray every 5 days

prevention_tips: Use ONLY certified disease-free seeds and transplants
Completely avoid overhead watering - use drip irrigation only
Remove and destroy infected plant parts immediately
Rotate tomatoes with non-host crops (corn, beans) for minimum 2 years
Disinfect all tools with 10% bleach solution after each use
Space plants widely (24-36 inches) for excellent air circulation
Apply preventive copper sprays before rainy season
Never work in tomato field when plants are wet
Use resistant varieties when available
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.when_to_treat: Start treatment IMMEDIATELY when first spots appear. Bacterial spot spreads extremely rapidly through water splash and can destroy entire crop within 2-3 weeks if untreated.

Tomato___Early_blight.description: Common fungal disease causing characteristic target-spot lesions on older leaves, leading to defoliation and reduced fruit quality
causes: Water stress alternating with wet periods

chemical_treatments.name: Mancozeb 75% WP
chemical_treatments.application: Spray every 7-10 days, start at first bloom

chemical_treatments.name: Chlorothalonil 75% WP
chemical_treatments.application: Apply at 10-day intervals during humid weather

chemical_treatments.name: Azoxystrobin 23% SC
chemical_treatments.application: Spray at 2-week intervals, alternate with other fungicides

organic_treatments.name: Baking Soda + Oil Spray
organic_treatments.dosage: 1 tablespoon baking soda + 1 tablespoon oil + few drops soap per liter
organic_treatments.application: Spray weekly, increases leaf pH making it unfavorable for fungus

organic_treatments.name: Compost Tea (Aerobic)
organic_treatments.dosage: 500ml well-aerated compost tea per liter water
organic_treatments.application: Spray twice weekly, beneficial microbes suppress disease

organic_treatments.name: Trichoderma viride
organic_treatments.application: Spray every 10 days throughout season

prevention_tips: Apply thick organic mulch (4-6 inches) around plants to prevent soil splash onto lower leaves
Water ONLY at soil level early in morning, never wet foliage
Remove and destroy lowest 4-6 leaves that touch soil
Stake or cage all tomato plants to improve air circulation and keep leaves off ground
Rotate tomatoes with non-solanaceous crops (corn, beans, squash) every 2-3 years
Remove and dispose of all infected leaves immediately (burn or trash, not compost)
Maintain proper plant nutrition, especially potassium and calcium
Space plants 24-36 inches apart
Apply preventive fungicide sprays starting at first flower
Tomato___Early_blight.when_to_treat: Begin treatment at first sign of target-spot lesions on lower leaves. Early blight is most effectively managed when caught early. Disease is most aggressive during fruit development stage.
